The Program Loan   
   
Program  The program seeks to help the state government of Mizoram (SGM) to 
Description  create fiscal space by (i) enhancing tax and nontax revenue measures 
and rationalizing expenditures; (ii) bringing about service improvements 
in two key sectors (health and education) in a cost-effective manner;  
(iii) ensuring better debt management; (iv) reforming the state pension 
system;  and  (v)  restructuring  public  sector  enterprises,  including 
through closure, as needed. 
   
Rationale  The rationale for the program is based on two underlying factors: (i) the 
political commitment of SGM to bring about necessary fiscal reforms to 
set the fiscal situation on a trajectory that is balanced, sustainable, and 
geared to meeting the long-term needs of the population of the state; 
and (ii) the need of the state economy for a program that takes a holistic 
view of fiscal reforms ranging from a focus on macro and, for example, 
medium-term expenditure frameworks to a focus on micro reforms such 
as ensuring that sector reforms contribute to improved service delivery 
and enhanced fiscal space. The program directly addresses key issues 
facing SGM as it tries to direct the economy on a more sustainable 
development path. 
   
Impact and  The  impact  of  the  program  will  be  evident  in  SGM  increasing 
Outcome  investments  of  public  funds  to  improve  inclusive  human  and  social 
development in the state. The program seeks an outcome of greater 
fiscal  space  in,  and  financial  flexibility  of,  the  government  budget 
resulting from: (i) increased tax and nontax revenues; (ii) rationalized 
expenditures in areas such as pensions and public sector enterprises, 
and through the adoption of medium-term expenditure frameworks in

health and education; (iii) debt restructuring; and (iv) improved services 
in two key sectors (health and education) in a cost-effective manner.

Asian Development Bank (ADB) will be provided to India under ADB’s 
London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility. The loan 
will have a 15-year term including a grace period of 3 years, an interest 
rate determined in accordance with ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility, 
a commitment charge of 0.15% per annum, and such other terms and 
conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement.  
 
The loan will be released in three tranches: (i) $47,000,000 for the first 
tranche, (ii) $40,000,000 for the second tranche, and (iii) $7,000,000 for 
the third tranche. The first tranche will be released upon fulfillment of all 
agreed conditions for the first tranche and following effectiveness of the 
loan.  The  second  tranche  will  be  disbursed  16  months  after  loan 
effectiveness upon satisfactory fulfillment of the corresponding tranche 
release conditions (or earlier than 16 months if the conditions have 
been met). The third tranche will be disbursed 14 months after the 
second tranche, subject to satisfactory fulfillment of the corresponding 
tranche release conditions (or earlier than 14 months if the conditions 
have been met).

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
loan to India for the Mizoram Public Resource Management Program, and (ii) a proposed 
technical  assistance  (TA)  loan  for  supporting  the  Program.  The  design  and  monitoring 
framework for the Program is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 
 
A.  Recent Economic Performance of India 
 
2.  India’s  economy  has  shown  impressive  growth  in  recent  years  with  strong 
macroeconomic  fundamentals  and  averaging  close  to  9%  over  the  5-year  period  ending 
2007/08. However, recent turmoil in the global economy has raised concerns about sustaining 
the impressive growth performance. Overall, growth is now expected to be around 6.7% for 
2008/09.  
 
3.  With  respect  to  fiscal  management,  the  gross  tax–gross  domestic  product  ratio 
increased from 9.2% in 2003/04 to 12.6% in 2007/08. The Government of India (Government) 
continued with progress in terms of reducing the revenue deficit and fiscal deficit, and increasing 
outlays  for  several  social  sector  and  infrastructure  development  programs.  However,  the 
process of fiscal consolidation being followed by the Government since 2004/05 has been 
disrupted by the current financial and economic crisis and related uncertainties. The central 
Government has justified temporarily postponing compliance with the targets set under the 
Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management (FRBM) Act in the context of the economic 
slowdown. The central government's fiscal deficit has risen to 6% of gross domestic product 
compared  with  2.5%  targeted  for  2008/09.  Both  revenue  shortfall  and  higher  expenditure 
contributed to the rise in the fiscal deficit. In the central budget for 2009/10, the Government has 
estimated a fiscal deficit of 6.8% for 2009/10 although it has also reiterated its commitment to 
reduce the fiscal deficit to a sustainable amount.   
 
B.  Recent Economic Performance of Mizoram 
 
4.  Regarded  as  a  small  state  (with  a  population  of  approximately  1  million  people), 
economic trends in Mizoram have not mirrored those of India as a whole. From 1999 to 2008, 
Mizoram’s growth rate of 6.2% was below the all-India average of 7.1%. While the gross state 
domestic product (GSDP) at factor cost in 2005/06 grew by 2.4% over the previous year, this 
increased to 5.5% in 2007/08 (advance estimates) due to robust performance in key service 
sectors such as finance, insurance, real estate, and business services.1 
 
5.  The state could experience some external shocks in the months to come, primarily 
because of the general slowing of the Indian economy (which could impact intergovernment 
fiscal transfers) and adverse impacts of pay revisions. Preliminary estimates suggest that the 
state government of Mizoram (SGM) requires an additional Rs3 billion annually to implement 
higher  salaries  of  government  employees.  This  brings  to  the  forefront  the  importance  of 
renewed attention to fiscal reform. The quality of public expenditure and usefulness of several 
public  programs  need  to  be  reviewed,  while  preventing  cutoffs  of  ongoing  infrastructure 
spending. Better targeting of food subsidies and improved tax efforts have become imperative 
for achieving a sustainable fiscal deficit and public debt.

1.  Fiscal Performance 
 
7.  If the fiscal health of a government is to be summarized in terms of a single indicator, it 
would be the gross fiscal deficit, i.e., the requirement of debts to implement spending decisions 
related to capital and current expenditures. High ratios portend high debt in the future along with 
increasing debt service liability that, in turn, limits resources available for development spending 
(Table 1 provides broad fiscal aggregates for the state). 
 
8.  The state has succeeded in substantially increasing its own revenues (both tax and 
nontax) since 2001/02, particularly from 2005/06. It has also managed to contain the growth of 
expenditures so that the revenue surplus has been sustained since 2003/04.  
 
9.  In Mizoram, the gross fiscal deficit fluctuated from 21.6% in 2000/01 to 6.4% in 2006/07. 
A redeeming feature is that revenue balances (indicating the state’s ability to finance its current 
expenditures from its current resources) have come down from a deficit of 11.1% in 2000/01 to 
a surplus of 6.5% of GSDP in 2008/09 (revised estimate). However, this achievement appeared 
to  be  inadequate  to  contain  the  fiscal  deficit  at  a  manageable  level  during  2007/08  and 
2008/09. 3 This  brings  to  the  forefront  the  need  for  expenditure  rationalization  through 
prioritization and evaluation of government programs.

12.  Own Receipts. During 2001/02 to 2007/08, revenue receipts increased by an average

14.  Debt Profile and Debt Servicing. The ratio of public debt to GSDP remained above

7.  Rationale 
 
41.  The rationale for the program is based on three underlying factors of why a program of 
this nature is relevant and important for a state such as Mizoram. 
 
(i)  First, it builds on the political commitment of SGM to bring about necessary fiscal 
reforms in the state so that it can set the fiscal situation on a trajectory that is 
balanced,  sustainable,  and  geared  to  meeting  the  long-term  needs  of  its 
population. 
(ii)  Second, the economy currently requires a program that takes a holistic view of 
fiscal reforms ranging from a focus on the macro (for example, MTEFs) to a 
focus on more micro reforms (such as ensuring that sector reforms contribute to 
improved service delivery and enhanced fiscal space). 
(iii)  Third, the desire of SGM to address the nonfiscal constraints currently evident in 
the core social services (i.e., education and health) is strong. The merit criterion 
is currently being undermined in the education sector through the continued 
engagement of underqualified teachers. This needs to change if Mizoram is to 
make gains in education. SGM is keen to ensure that its population has easy 
access to basic health care services, and recognizes that accessibility of such 
services will ensure that the population can participate fully in development. 
 
42.  The program thus directly addresses key issues facing SGM as it tries to move the 
economy to a more sustainable path of reforms.

  5.  Pension Reforms 
 
52.  SGM currently has a defined benefits scheme in place that places considerable pressure 
on the state treasury. The program proposes the adoption of the defined contribution system of 
pensions for new government employees joining on or after a cutoff date. However, in the short 
term, the defined contributory pension system puts additional pressure on state finances as 
SGM must pay the pension liabilities of its employees under the old defined benefit system as 
well as make contributions under the defined contribution system for new employees. The 
program thus focuses on a modality of putting employees’ deduction and SGM’s contribution 
system in place, as well as initiating the agreement between the pension fund manager and 
SGM. It also envisages providing financial support to meet SGM’s contributions for the defined 
contributory  pension  scheme  for  new  employees  (such  a  scheme  for  central  Government 
employees has been in place since 1 April 2004; many states have also implemented the new 
pension scheme). 
 
  6.  Public Sector Enterprise (PSE) Reforms 
 
53.  The state’s PSEs have historically been a fiscal drag on public finances. The five loss-
making  PSEs  all  urgently  need  comprehensive  reforms,  including  downsizing  or  closure. 
Moreover, the PSEs have not been keeping up-to-date audited accounts. Given this situation, 
the program supports SGM efforts to initiate an effective PSE reform program including closure 
or privatization where desirable. The program targets: (i) an options analysis on restructuring 
and/or consolidating the PSEs, including privatization or closure (as well as labor rehabilitation 
plans, as needed); (ii) specific public awareness campaigns that are a part of the PSE reform 
exercise; and (iii) notification of closure of all PSEs that are recommended for closure.30 
 
C.  Special Features  
 
54.  The  following  features  of  the  program  are  noteworthy:  (i)  it  builds  on  the  political 
commitment of SGM to bring about necessary fiscal reforms in the state; (ii) it takes a holistic 
view of fiscal reforms ranging from a focus on the macro to more micro reforms such as 
ensuring that sector reforms contribute to improved service delivery and enhance fiscal space; 
(iii) its design draws on the experiences of similar programs not only within the states of India 
(Assam, Gujarat, Kerala, and Madhya Pradesh) but also other countries in the region (such as 
Pakistan and Sri Lanka); and finally (iv) the program directly addresses key issues facing SGM 
as it tries to direct the economy to a more sustainable path of reforms.

VI.  PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
 
A.  Benefits and Impacts 
 
88.  The expected benefits of the program will be evident at the macro level in the creation of 
greater fiscal space for SGM, which will enable it to make greater investments in social and 
economic  development  activities.  The  program  loan  will  help  improve  SGM’s  revenue 
administration, and strengthen expenditure management and debt management; it will also put 
state economic reforms on a sustainable path. 
 
89.  The program benefits are expected to be evident in: (i) the availability of more resources 
to invest in social and economic infrastructure in the state, which should ultimately assist in 
enhancing the welfare of the poor in rural areas; (ii) more efficient allocation of budget resources 
based on outcomes sought rather than in an incremental and ad hoc manner; and (iii) the ability 
of SGM, in the long term, to place its fiscal affairs on a sounder footing that can sustain 
investments for more rapid and inclusive growth. The program will help SGM to gain specific 
benefits in the following: 
 
(i)  greater consideration of outcomes and medium-term considerations in resource 
allocations (largely through reliance on the MTEFs); 
(ii)  better  pension  management  for  SGM  employees  (by  moving  to  a  defined 
contribution scheme from one of defined benefits); 
(iii)  more streamlined tax administration; 
(iv)  more objective valuation of fixed public assets, such as properties; 
(v)  better handling of risk-based audits; 
(vi)  more effective treasuries given their computerization; 
(vii)  better knowledge of the contingent liabilities of the state, and better management 
of the debt overhang; 
(viii)  improved services in the education sector through the recruitment of qualified 
teachers to replace underqualified ones;38 and 
(ix)  ability to put the MHC Scheme on a sustainable footing given the establishment 
of the corpus to ensure continued availability of funds to meet the annual costs of 
scheme management. 
 
90.  In the long-term, as the program seeks to strengthen SGM’s fiscal affairs, the economic 
growth rate should respond positively. If indeed the state is to catch up to the all-India average 
gross domestic product growth rate, then creation of greater fiscal space and improvements of 
services in key sectors are the only viable options in the short and medium term. A higher 
growth rate and GSDP will mean that the entire public will eventually benefit from the program. 
The impact of the Program should also be felt in the medium term by the poor in rural areas; this 
is expected to be direct in cases of health and education, and indirect in other cases of fiscal 
reforms in the state economy. The program should create opportunities for SGM to invest in 
much-needed infrastructure that will allow the broader state economy to be better integrated. A 
summary poverty reduction analysis is presented in Appendix 9.

2.  Results of Reliance on the Central Government

composition of expenditures is not largely the state‘s own making, implying its correspondingly

1.  Link  to  National  Poverty  Reduction  Strategy  and  Country  Partnership

1.  The  Government  of  India‘s  strategy  for  poverty  reduction  focuses  on  infrastructure 
development, social development, and agriculture and rural development for more inclusive 
growth. The approach paper to the 11th Five Year Plan also reaffirms the importance of strong 
state government fiscal management. ADB country partnership strategy and country operations 
business  plan  for  India1  emphasize  these  objectives  through  public–private  partnerships, 
agribusiness  infrastructure,  rural  finance,  irrigation,  and  improved  water  resources 
management.  
 
2.  Poverty Analysis 
 
2.  Key  Issues.  Two  key  issues  dominate  the  poverty  aspects  of  fiscal  management 
reforms: (i) Human poverty as distinct from income poverty: poverty has to be seen not only in 
terms of income but also in terms of, for example, accessibility to affordable services. The 
Program  argues  that  necessary  fiscal  reforms  have  to  be  translated  into  measurable 
improvements in services in social sectors. (ii) Capacity building: reducing poverty through 
macroeconomic and fiscal reforms is only possible when the policy reform agenda is backed by 
strong capacity of government departments to deliver on the reform agenda. 
 
3.  Main findings from the poverty and social assessment also reveal that while the program 
does not directly impact poverty reduction in the state, three specific  issues are relevant:  
(i) more streamlined tax and nontax revenue reforms mean a fair system with no bias against 
low-income groups; (ii) proper debt management and rationalization of expenditures mean the 
fiscal space for greater social spending directly impacts poor people; and (iii) the impacts of 
social investments in health and education are more directly visible on the poor. 
 
4.  Design Features. Important features of the program are: (i) support for SGM to continue 
its focus on economic  and social development; (ii) help for  SGM to better align resource 
allocation to desired long-term outcomes in two sectors; (iii) help for SGM to carry forward its 
reform agenda in the social sectors; and (iv) alignment with the outcomes and new initiatives of 
SGM in the area of fiscal reforms and management (this includes the reform agenda that the 
new government is pursuing).

Brief Narrative  
The poverty impact of the program is expected to be manifest in: (i) in the short term, key changes will be made in the service delivery systems in the health and 
education sectors (including introduction of the merit principle in the school system); (ii) in the medium-term, SGM will be better able to channel resources for social 
development purposes given that ADB assistance will have enabled it to create the necessary fiscal space, which will free up investment resources; and (iii) finally, 
in the long term, a rigorous expenditure framework in the health and education sectors will ensure that the government effectively targets resources to desired 
outcomes with assured amount of resources. All these will ultimately, albeit in an indirect manner, have a positive impact on the poor. The conceptual basis of all 
these three points is in the link between fiscal reforms leading to macroeconomic stability and pro-poor growth and social and economic development.
